lessons.title: Parts of Speech
lessons.content: Learn the main parts of speech: nouns, pronouns, verbs, adjectives, adverbs, prepositions, conjunctions, and interjections. Understanding parts of speech helps us construct proper sentences and communicate effectively.

quiz.text: Identify the noun in: 'The teacher writes.'
Identify the verb in: 'Birds fly high.'

lessons.title: Tenses
lessons.content: Learn the three main tenses: past, present, and future. Each tense shows when an action occurs. Understanding tenses helps us communicate clearly about time.

examples.problem: Future tense: 'She will walk to school.'
solution: Step 1: Identify when action will happen

quiz.text: Identify tense: 'I wrote a letter yesterday.'

lessons.title: Subject-Verb Agreement
lessons.content: Learn to make the subject and verb agree in number (singular or plural). This creates grammatically correct sentences that are clear and professional.

lessons.title: Active and Passive Voice
lessons.content: Learn to convert sentences from active to passive voice and vice versa. Active voice makes writing more direct and engaging, while passive voice emphasizes the action rather than the actor.

solution: Step 2: Move object to front: 'The mouse'
Step 3: Add 'was' + past participle: 'was chased by the cat'

examples.problem: Passive: 'The book was read by her.'
solution: Step 1: Identify subject (book), verb (was read), actor (her)
Step 3: Use simple past: 'She read the book'

options: An apple is eaten by him
He is eaten by an apple

quiz.text: Passive: 'The letter was written by me.' Active?
Passive: 'The cake was baked by John.' Active?

options: A song is sung by her

quiz.text: Passive: 'The room was cleaned by them.' Active?

options: A letter is written by me

quiz.text: Passive: 'The homework was done by the students.' Active?
Passive: 'The song was sung by the choir.' Active?

lessons.title: Punctuation
lessons.content: Learn correct use of punctuation marks: period, comma, question mark, exclamation mark, colon, semicolon, quotation marks. Proper punctuation makes writing clear and professional.

solution: Step 2: Add question mark for questions

quiz.text: Add punctuation: 'She said I am coming'
Add punctuation: 'He asked where are you going'

lessons.title: Synonyms & Antonyms
lessons.content: Learn words with similar meanings (synonyms) and opposite meanings (antonyms). Building vocabulary through synonyms and antonyms helps express ideas more precisely and improves writing variety.

solution: Step 1: Think of words with similar meaning
Step 3: All have similar meaning to 'happy'
Step 1: Think of words with opposite meaning

lessons.title: Homophones & Homonyms
lessons.content: Learn words that sound the same but have different meanings (homophones) and words that are spelled the same but have different meanings (homonyms). These can be tricky but understanding them improves spelling and comprehension.

solution: Step 2: One is a flying animal

lessons.title: Idioms & Phrases
lessons.content: Learn common English idioms and phrases, and their meanings. Idioms make language colorful and help you understand native speakers better.

solution: Step 2: It doesn't mean literally break a leg
Step 2: It doesn't mean actual cake

quiz.text: Meaning of 'Once in a blue moon'?
Meaning of 'Cost an arm and a leg'?
Meaning of 'Let the cat out of the bag'?
Meaning of 'Hit the nail on the head'?

lessons.title: Word Formation
lessons.content: Learn how new words are formed using prefixes, suffixes, and root words. Understanding word formation helps you figure out meanings of unfamiliar words and expand your vocabulary.

solution: Step 2: Add suffix '-ness' to form noun
Step 3: Result: 'Happiness' (noun meaning state of being happy)
Step 2: Add prefix 'Un-' to form opposite

lessons.title: Contextual Vocabulary
lessons.content: Learn to choose the correct word based on context and sentence meaning. This skill helps you communicate more precisely and understand texts better.

examples.problem: He entered the room ____ and quietly.
solution: Step 2: Think of words that match 'quietly'

quiz.text: Fill: He is very ___ at football.
Choose: She ran ___ to catch the bus.

lessons.title: Understanding Passages
lessons.content: Learn how to read passages carefully to understand the main idea, details, and context. Good reading comprehension is essential for academic success and lifelong learning.

examples.problem: Passage: 'The sun rises in the east.' What is the main idea?
solution: Step 3: Main idea: The sun rises in a particular direction, east

examples.problem: Passage: 'Many birds migrate in winter.' What detail supports this?
solution: Step 3: Detail: Birds travel to warmer areas during winter

quiz.text: What is the main idea of: 'Cats are playful animals.'
Detail: 'She wore a red dress and a hat.' What color is the dress?
Infer: 'He ran to catch the bus.' What can you infer?
Detail: 'The cat slept on the sofa all day.' Where did the cat sleep?
Infer: 'She studied all night.' What can you infer?
Detail: 'He ate an apple and a banana.' Which fruits did he eat?
Infer: 'She wore sunglasses.' What can you infer?

lessons.title: Main Idea & Details
lessons.content: Learn how to identify the main idea and supporting details in a passage. The main idea is the central point, while details provide evidence or examples to support it.

examples.problem: Passage: 'Many students enjoy sports.' Main idea?
solution: Step 1: Identify what the passage is mainly about
Step 2: Focus on the central point
Step 3: Main idea: Sports are popular among students

examples.problem: Supporting detail: 'Football, basketball, and tennis are popular.'
solution: Step 1: Identify how this relates to main idea
Step 3: Supporting detail: Examples of sports students enjoy

quiz.text: Supporting detail: 'She wore a red dress.'

lessons.title: Inference & Prediction
lessons.content: Learn how to make logical guesses (inferences) and predict what happens next in a passage. These skills help you understand implied meanings and engage actively with texts.

examples.problem: Sentence: 'He packed an umbrella.' What can you infer?
solution: Step 1: Consider why someone packs umbrella

examples.problem: Predict: 'She opened the gift.' What will she do?
solution: Step 1: Consider what happens after opening gift
Step 3: Prediction: She will see what's inside

lessons.title: Summarizing
lessons.content: Learn to write brief summaries capturing the main idea and key details of a passage. Summarizing helps you understand and remember important information.

examples.problem: Passage: 'Dogs bark, cats meow, and birds chirp.'
solution: Step 3: Summary: Different animals make different sounds

examples.problem: Passage: 'She likes reading books every day.'
solution: Step 3: Summary: She enjoys daily reading

quiz.text: Summarize: 'The sun rises in the east and sets in the west.'
Summarize: 'The boy ate an apple and a banana.'
Summarize: 'She studied all night for the test.'
Summarize: 'He cleaned his room and washed dishes.'
Summarize: 'The teacher explained the lesson and gave homework.'
Summarize: 'He drank water and ate food.'
Summarize: 'She smiled and waved at her friend.'
Summarize: 'The children played football and basketball.'

lessons.title: Answering Questions from Texts
lessons.content: Learn how to answer comprehension questions based on a given passage, focusing on details and inference. This skill is essential for academic success and standardized tests.

examples.problem: Passage: 'She wore a red dress.' Question: What color?
solution: Step 1: Locate relevant information in passage

examples.problem: Passage: 'He ran fast.' Question: How did he run?

quiz.text: Passage: 'The sun rises in the east.' Question: Where does it rise?
Passage: 'Birds fly in the sky.' Question: What do birds do?
Passage: 'He drank water.' Question: What did he drink?
Passage: 'She read a book.' Question: What did she read?
Passage: 'It rained heavily.' Question: What happened?
Passage: 'The boy plays football.' Question: What sport?
Passage: 'She sang beautifully.' Question: How did she sing?
Passage: 'He is tall.' Question: How is he?
Passage: 'Dogs bark at strangers.' Question: Who barks?
Passage: 'She smiled and waved.' Question: What did she do?

lessons.title: Sentence Construction
lessons.content: Learn how to write correct and complete sentences using proper grammar and punctuation. Good sentence construction is the foundation of clear communication.

lessons.title: Paragraph Writing
lessons.content: Learn to write structured paragraphs with topic sentences, supporting details, and conclusions. Good paragraphs organize ideas clearly and help readers follow your thoughts.

solution: Step 1: Start with topic sentence about your hobby
Step 2: Add 2-3 supporting details explaining why you like it
Step 3: End with conclusion summarizing your feelings
Step 1: Introduce the day and why it was memorable
Step 2: Describe the main events that happened
Step 3: Conclude with how you felt about the experience

lessons.title: Letter Writing
lessons.content: Learn how to write formal and informal letters, including proper greetings, body, and closing. Letter writing skills are useful for academic and professional communication.

examples.problem: Formal letter: Complaint about late delivery
solution: Step 1: Include sender and receiver addresses
Step 2: Add date and formal greeting
Step 3: Write body explaining the complaint
Step 4: End with formal closing and signature
Step 2: Write body sharing news or feelings

lessons.title: Essay Writing
lessons.content: Learn to write structured essays with introduction, body paragraphs, and conclusion. Essay writing develops critical thinking and helps you express complex ideas clearly.

solution: Step 1: Write introduction with thesis statement
Step 2: Add 2-3 body paragraphs with supporting arguments
Step 3: Write conclusion that reinforces main points
Step 2: Explain reasons with specific details

lessons.title: Creative Writing
lessons.content: Learn to write stories, poems, or descriptive passages using imagination and proper language. Creative writing develops imagination and self-expression skills.

examples.problem: Story: A day at the beach
solution: Step 2: Introduce characters and their activities
Step 3: Describe events with sensory details
Step 4: Express emotions about the season

lessons.title: Parts of Speech
lessons.content: Learn about nouns, pronouns, verbs, adjectives, adverbs, prepositions, conjunctions, and interjections. Mastering parts of speech helps you understand how words function in sentences.

examples.problem: Identify the noun: 'The cat sleeps on the mat.'
solution: Step 2: 'cat' names an animal, 'mat' names an object

quiz.text: Identify the adjective: 'The red ball is mine.'
Identify the pronoun: 'He is my friend.'
Identify the conjunction: 'I like tea and coffee.'
Identify the preposition: 'The book is on the table.'
Identify the noun: 'Birds fly in the sky.'

lessons.title: Tenses
lessons.content: Learn about past, present, and future tenses and how to use them correctly. Proper tense usage ensures clear communication about when actions occur.

examples.problem: Future tense: 'She (will/walk) to the park tomorrow.'

lessons.title: Active & Passive Voice
lessons.content: Learn how to convert sentences from active voice to passive voice and vice versa. Understanding both voices helps you vary your writing style and emphasize different elements.

solution: Step 2: Move object to front: 'The mouse'
Step 3: Add 'was' + past participle: 'The mouse was chased by the cat'

examples.problem: Passive: 'The cake was baked by Mary.'
solution: Step 3: Use active form: 'Mary baked the cake'

options: A letter was written by him.

quiz.text: Passive: 'The book was read by Tom.' Active?

options: The wall was painted by her.

quiz.text: Passive: 'The homework was done by the students.' Active?

options: A house was built by them.

quiz.text: Passive: 'The song was sung by her.' Active?

options: The room was cleaned by me.

quiz.text: Passive: 'The movie was watched by them.' Active?

options: The door was closed by her.

quiz.text: Passive: 'The letter was written by John.' Active?

lessons.title: Punctuation & Capitalization
lessons.content: Learn to use punctuation marks and capitalization correctly in sentences. Proper punctuation and capitalization make writing clear, professional, and easy to read.

solution: Step 2: Add comma before address: 'Let's eat, grandma'

quiz.text: Punctuation: 'I like apples oranges and bananas'
options: I like apples, oranges, and bananas.
I like apples oranges and bananas.
I like apples; oranges and bananas.
I like apples. Oranges and bananas.

quiz.text: Punctuation: 'He asked Where are you going'
options: He asked, Where are you going?
He asked Where are you going?

lessons.title: Common Errors & Usage
lessons.content: Learn to identify and correct common grammar mistakes in writing and speaking. Avoiding these errors makes your communication more professional and effective.

lessons.title: Synonyms & Antonyms
lessons.content: Learn the meaning of words and identify synonyms (words with similar meanings) and antonyms (words with opposite meanings). This expands your vocabulary and improves your ability to express ideas precisely.

solution: Step 1: Think of words with similar meaning
Step 1: Think of words with opposite meaning

lessons.title: Homophones & Homonyms
lessons.content: Learn words that sound the same but have different meanings (homophones) and words with multiple meanings (homonyms). Understanding these prevents common spelling and usage errors.

solution: Step 3: 'Bear' is a large animal or means to carry
Step 2: 'Bat' can be a flying mammal
Step 3: 'Bat' can also be sports equipment

lessons.title: Prefixes & Suffixes
lessons.content: Learn how prefixes and suffixes change the meaning of base words. This knowledge helps you understand new vocabulary and build words systematically.

lessons.title: Spelling Rules
lessons.content: Learn common spelling rules and patterns to improve accuracy in writing. Mastering these rules helps you spell unfamiliar words correctly and reduces spelling errors.

examples.problem: i before e except after c: 'receive'

solution: Step 1: Check if word ends in consonant-vowel-consonant

lessons.title: Idioms & Phrases
lessons.content: Learn common idioms and phrases, their meanings, and how to use them in sentences. Idioms add color to language and help you understand native speakers better.

solution: Step 1: This is a figurative expression
Step 2: It doesn't mean literally breaking ice
Step 3: Meaning: To initiate conversation in a social setting
Step 1: This is a figurative expression
Step 2: It doesn't refer to actual cake
Step 3: Meaning: A very easy task

quiz.text: Meaning of 'Once in a blue moon'?
Meaning of 'Let the cat out of the bag'?
Meaning of 'Cost an arm and a leg'?

lessons.title: Understanding the Main Idea
lessons.content: Learn how to identify the main idea of a passage and summarize it. The main idea is the central message or most important point the author wants to communicate.

examples.problem: Passage: 'Dogs are loyal animals. They are friendly and protect their owners.'
solution: Step 2: Identify what the passage is mainly about
Step 3: Main idea: Dogs are loyal and protective animals

examples.problem: Passage: 'Trees produce oxygen and provide shade.'
solution: Step 2: Note what they do (produce oxygen, provide shade)
Step 3: Main idea: Trees benefit the environment

quiz.text: Main idea: 'The sun provides heat and light to the earth.'
options: The sun is important for life

quiz.text: Main idea: 'Cats are independent animals and can take care of themselves.'
Main idea: 'Rain helps plants grow and fills rivers.'
options: Rain is essential for plants and water bodies

quiz.text: Main idea: 'Reading improves vocabulary and imagination.'
Main idea: 'Exercise keeps the body healthy.'
Main idea: 'Birds build nests to lay eggs.'
Main idea: 'Electricity powers homes and devices.'
Main idea: 'Water is needed for drinking and cooking.'
Main idea: 'Trees reduce pollution and provide oxygen.'

lessons.title: Identifying Supporting Details
lessons.content: Learn to identify supporting details that explain or reinforce the main idea. Supporting details provide evidence, examples, or specific information that backs up the central point.

examples.problem: Passage: 'Birds migrate to warmer regions during winter. They look for food and a suitable climate.'
solution: Step 2: Find details that support this
Step 3: Supporting details: migrate to warmer regions, look for food, suitable climate

examples.problem: Passage: 'Exercise keeps us fit. Running and swimming are good examples.'
solution: Step 1: Identify main idea (exercise keeps us fit)
Step 3: Supporting details: Running and swimming are good examples of exercise

quiz.text: Supporting detail: 'Cats are playful. They like chasing toys.'
Supporting detail: 'Water is vital. It keeps our body hydrated.'
Supporting detail: 'The sun rises in the east. It provides light and warmth.'
Supporting detail: 'Reading books improves vocabulary. Reading novels helps imagination.'
Supporting detail: 'Trees provide oxygen. They also give shade.'
Supporting detail: 'Birds lay eggs. They also feed their chicks.'
Supporting detail: 'Exercise is important. Swimming and jogging are good examples.'
Supporting detail: 'Rainwater is collected in tanks. It is used for gardening.'
Supporting detail: 'Electricity powers lights. It also powers fans and TVs.'
Supporting detail: 'Milk is nutritious. It contains calcium.'

lessons.title: Making Inferences
lessons.content: Learn to draw conclusions based on information that is implied but not directly stated. Inference skills help you understand deeper meanings and read between the lines.

examples.problem: Passage: 'John came home with wet clothes.'
solution: Step 1: Consider why clothes would be wet
Step 3: Inference: It was raining outside or he was in water

examples.problem: Passage: 'The ground was covered with snow.'
solution: Step 1: Consider when snow covers ground
Step 3: Inference: It is winter or very cold weather

quiz.text: Infer: 'He was shivering and wearing a coat.'
Infer: 'She has a cast on her leg.'
Infer: 'The lights were off in the house.'
Infer: 'The boy ran to the bus stop.'
options: He wants to catch the bus

quiz.text: Infer: 'The sky is dark and cloudy.'

options: She has a lot of items

lessons.title: Drawing Conclusions
lessons.content: Learn to combine information from the passage and your knowledge to reach logical conclusions. This skill helps you understand texts more deeply and think critically.

examples.problem: Passage: 'It is cloudy and the ground is wet.'
solution: Step 1: Combine the clues (cloudy + wet ground)

examples.problem: Passage: 'She wore a raincoat and boots.'
solution: Step 1: Consider why someone wears raincoat and boots
Step 3: Conclusion: The weather is rainy or wet

quiz.text: Conclusion: 'He wore a hat and scarf.'
Conclusion: 'The boy is sweating and drinking water.'
Conclusion: 'He wore gloves and a coat.'
Conclusion: 'The sky has many dark clouds.'
Conclusion: 'The girl shivered and rubbed her hands.'
Conclusion: 'The ice is melting on the road.'

lessons.title: Answering Questions from Passages
lessons.content: Learn to answer direct and inferential questions based on reading passages. This skill is essential for academic success and standardized tests.

examples.problem: Passage: 'Dogs bark at strangers to protect their home.' Question: 'Why do dogs bark at strangers?'
solution: Step 1: Locate relevant information in passage
Step 3: Answer: To protect their home

examples.problem: Passage: 'The sun rises in the east.' Question: 'Where does the sun rise?'
solution: Step 1: Find the specific information asked

quiz.text: Passage: 'The sun rises in the east.' Question: Where does it rise?
Passage: 'Birds fly in the sky.' Question: What do birds do?
Passage: 'He drank water.' Question: What did he drink?
Passage: 'She read a book.' Question: What did she read?
Passage: 'It rained heavily.' Question: What happened?
Passage: 'The boy plays football.' Question: What sport?
Passage: 'She sang beautifully.' Question: How did she sing?
Passage: 'He is tall.' Question: How is he?
Passage: 'Dogs bark at strangers.' Question: Who barks?
Passage: 'She smiled and waved.' Question: What did she do?
